content_blocks.text: Mathematics is, in large part, the search for patterns, and for the explanations as to why those patterns exist. Such patterns indeed exist all around us — in nature, in our homes and schools, and in the motion of the sun, moon, and stars.
The branch of Mathematics that studies patterns in whole numbers is called number theory.
Table 1 shows some key number sequences that are studied in Mathematics.
Number sequences are the most basic and among the most fascinating types of patterns that mathematicians study.
Patterns in mathematics refer to the repetition of a specific shape, number, or design in a predictable and consistent manner.
Numerical patterns can be created by adding or multiplying numbers in a specific way, such as adding consecutive numbers or multiplying triangular numbers by 6 and adding 1.
For example, the sequence 1, 1 + 2 + 1, 1 + 2 + 3 + 2 + 1, … gives square numbers when adding counting numbers up and down.
Shape patterns can be created by arranging shapes in a specific way, such as creating a triangle by arranging dots in a triangular pattern.
For example, the sequence 1, 1 + 7, 1 + 7 + 19, 1 + 7 + 19 + 37, … gives hexagonal numbers when adding hexagonal numbers.
Sequences are a series of numbers or shapes that follow a specific pattern or rule.
Powers of 2 can be created by multiplying 2 by itself a specific number of times, such as 2^1, 2^2, 2^3, …
For example, the sequence 1, 1 + 2, 1 + 2 + 4, 1 + 2 + 4 + 8, … gives powers of 2 when adding powers of 2 starting with 1.
Mathematics may be viewed as the search for patterns and for the explanations as to why those patterns exist.
Some important examples of number sequences include the counting numbers, odd numbers, even numbers, square numbers, triangular numbers, cube numbers, Virahānka numbers, and powers of 2.
Adding up the sequence of odd numbers starting with 1 gives square numbers.
Shape sequences are another basic type of pattern in mathematics.
Some important examples of shape sequences include regular polygons, complete graphs, stacked triangles and squares, and Koch snowflake iterations.
Visualising number sequences using pictures can help to understand sequences and the relationships between them.

content_blocks.text: Many number sequences can be visualised using pictures. Visualising mathematical objects through pictures or diagrams can be a very fruitful way to understand mathematical patterns and concepts.
Triangular numbers are numbers that can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of an equilateral triangle.
1, 3, 6, 10, 15, … are triangular numbers because they can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of an equilateral triangle.
Square numbers are numbers that can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a square grid.
1, 4, 9, 16, 25, … are square numbers because they can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a square grid.
Cubes are numbers that can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a cube.
1, 8, 27, 64, 125, … are cubes because they can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a cube.
Hexagonal numbers are numbers that can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a hexagon.
1, 7, 19, 37 are hexagonal numbers because they can be represented as dots arranged in the shape of a hexagon.
Powers of 2 are numbers that can be represented as 2 raised to a power.
1, 2, 4, 8, 16, … are powers of 2 because they can be represented as 2 raised to a power.
Powers of 3 are numbers that can be represented as 3 raised to a power.
1, 3, 9, 27, 81, … are powers of 3 because they can be represented as 3 raised to a power.
